note.p: Letter written by occupant of Anna Liffey House, Lucan during the Easter Rising. The author is one of the three Shackleton family members, John, George or perhaps Rebecca. The recipient is unknown.

text.body:
Anna Liffey House, Lucan Tuesday 25.4.1916 Dear C
There may be a letter from you now in the G. P. O. but its unlikely
that I'll ever get it. At this present moment the G P O is in the
possession of the Sinn Feiners (Irish Volunteers) — the Sinn Fein flag
is flying and Civil War reigns in Dublin.
An Irish Republic has been proclaimed. W. Connolly (Larkin's right
hand man) — ;as President.</
Later. I have since learned Connolly was Vice President commander-in-chief
and H P Pearse was President.
This sounds very melodramatic, but it is true nevertheless - yest-
erday (Easter Monday) when most of the decent populace of Dublin (includ-ing
the Military) were away at Fairythohouse Races — the rebels began their
work.
By 3.o'clock they had taken all the railway stations and all the
principal buildings in the city, including the General P. O. the Four
Courts, the S D Union, the Royal College of Surgeons, etc, they had
surrounded the Castle and had placed armed sentries at all
the bridges.
They have also taken Jacob's Biscuit Factory and yesterday there
was talk that they were going to blow the place up; they shot the sentry
and took the Powder Magazine in the Park.
I couln't believe my ears yesterday afternoon when a man telephoned
out from town and imparted all this news .
My brother and sister had gone to Fairyho, so I was alone, and had
to possess my soul in patience till they returned some hours later.
They had heard rumours of rioting in town, but did not think much
of it as there does be such wild talk going these times but they did notice
that soldiers before returning to town in motors, were all trying to get
a hold of caps and hats to hide their identity.
Lots of troops have arrived in town from the Curragh and there is
talk of machine guns being brought into the city, but the train service
is much dislocated; the rebels have blown up parts of the Midland line;
the telephone may notnow be used except for military purposes and for calling
doctors so we are very much cut off - no telegrams - no letters- no telephone
calls.
Rumour has it that the city of Cork is in the hands of Sinn
Feiners and that 30,000 Germans (first it was 10,000) have landed
in Kerry. This last tit-bit was from our breadman's boy, so from that
unreliable authority I take it with a grain of salt! Be that as it
may, the serious side of the thing is that German money is at the back;
and also we fear German organisation.
Later. This evening we hear that the G. P. O. is now in the hands of the
military ( A false report The Sinn Feiners held the G P O until the end)
and that many Sinn Feiners have been taken prisoners — Thank goodness —
but there's been a deal of blood-shed and many and many soldiers killed,
including a Colonel, officers and many men of the 5th Lancers.
The rebels have entrenched themselves in Stephen's Green and the
Military are now firing from the Shelbourne Hotel — my nephew cycled into
town today to see what he could see; he did not get further than Parliam-ent
St they were firing out of the City Hall, but he could not make out
whether Sinn Feiners or soldiers were in possession. He was told soldiers
but only rifles sticking out of the windows were visible. No police-men
anywhere about; one was killed yesterday at the Custom House and one
at the Castle of course they haven't a chance against rifles.
We've been to the village of Lucan this evening; there are couples
of mounted infantry stationed at different points and we understand there
are many more in ambush. It is rumoured the Sinn Feiners are likely
to give trouble in this district.
Leixlip (about a mile from Lucan) has for long been a hot-bed of
Sinn Feminism and Larkinism rather a deadly combination. About a
month ago some live bombs were discovered there in a drain by some child-ren
playing. There was a bit of excitement about it at the time, but
as usual no serious investigations were made and the scare died out.
The Leixlip bombs were evidently for blowing up the railway viaduct
when the time arrived. Wednesday A M
The news this A M is not cheering; Halligan's Mills (Flour Mills
in the city corresponding to ours) have been blown up; as my informant
remarked 'Halligan's Mills are as if they had never been'. (I saw
Halligan's Mills later; it was intact, as far as the building itself went.)
Bolands Mills (Boland's was taken early on by the rebels, who kept
the bakers there making bread for them), are also being shelled; I believe
by the Military to get out the rebels.
As against this is the good news that Liberty Hall has been shelled to
pieces by the Military big guns ranging from Phibsboro. Even here, at the
bottom of our garden (and sometimes from the house too) the guns can be
heard. On Thursday the rebels were given the chance to surrender but,
as they refused, they began to hammer them at 2 o'clock and they have been
at it ever since.
A great part of the city is fenced in barbed wire and now not only
unsafe but impossible to get in or out. The carnage in Sackville St
is something dreadful; picture to yourself trenches and barbed wire
fences in Sackville St. The Sinn Feiners have taken possession of
the houses on each side and without knocking down the houses and killing
quantities of women and children they cannot be got out. The women and
children refuse to go out; so you may imagine what is happening. Thursday.
We have been to Howth to visit two aunts who live there, taking
a circuitous route thro' the country. We found them in a bad way.
Food is getting very scarce and Howth is completely cur off from
supplies. While at Howth we heard that 10,000 troops have arrived
from England and that two battleships are in the Bay, but we are hearing
all sorts of things. One thing I've just heard with sorrow, is that the
G P O has been blown up (We hear different stories about the G P O every
day. The truth is the Rebels held it all through although the shell (granite) of
the outer walls is standing and the pillars of the portico are intact.The
roof is gone).
It had to be done, it was so strongly held by the rebels; I'm
afraid lots of the buildings will have the same fate. Dublin will present
a very ruined appearance when the turmoil has subsided. It may be days
and it may be weeks before they get the rebels under. We hear a great
many of the National Volunteers (John Redmonds) have gone over to the side
of the Irish Volunteers and we have also heard a rumour that the rebels
have bombarded Tallamore Goal and liberated a couple of thousands of German
who were imprisoned there; and these have been added to their forces.
Certain it is that among the killed are some German officers.
Friday A.M.
Things are going on much the same; neither better or worse; but its
almost impossible for us to judge. The whole countyside from far and
wide are flocking to the mill for flour; there is always a long queue
outside the mill-gate; rich and poor all have to take their turn; they are
now let in singly or they would storm the place.
We hear that Sir Thomas Myles has been shot (our leading Dublin
surgeon) and when all is over, I'm afraid we'll hear of many more civilians
who have been killed or wounded. Up till now the number
of casualities of the British Army's as against the Irish Volunteers is I'm afraid much
bigger. As the troops were marching into Dublin they were being potted outpat
all the time by the rebels from the houses. It is terrible to think these
English soldiers who were training to fight the Germans abroad have had to
come over to Dublin to be shot down in such a way. It is unbearable to
think of; We, in Ireland, can never hold our heads up again. The Irish
Regiments (of the B Army) who are in Dublin are all confined to barracks.
They could not be asked to fight against their own; and it is feared
they would side with the rebels. (This is only true in part; The Irish
Regts have done well in putting down the Rebels.)
We are now under Martial Law and all must be in their houses by 6 30
\P M The other evening, when our cook was on her way home from the village
she heard one of the Village brats playing on a tin whistle 'A Nation once
Again'. I would have made short work of him if I had heard him!
My brother, George, went into Marlboro' Barracks last evening with
the motor lorry to take flour to the soldiers, they were living on biscuits.
The rebels are armed many of the them with up-to-date German rifles and
ammunition and they have plenty of machine guns.The other day a hearse
was let into the city and because it was a hearse and it was found to be
full of ammunition for the Sinn Feiners. Stephen's green is now clear
(except for a certain number of rebels, led by Countess Markievins)
in the Royal College of Surgeons, and the hottest part of the fight is in
Sackville St, Abbey St, and along the Quays, particularly about the Four
Courts. The Military are firing from the south side across the river
to the Four Courts and Four Courts Hotel which is packed with rebels. Sunday A.M 30. 4. 1916.
Last evening at about 5 30 the Sinn Feiners surrendered uncondition-ally
(the Sinn Feiners under Pearse had surrendered but Connolly's gang were
still at large from their fortress, the G P O and about 150 rebels were
still in Jacob's sniping away as hard as they could).
We heard the news at Clonsilla (on my way home from a second
expedition to Howth). The past week seemed like an awful dream; particle-arly
out here at Anna Liffey this lovely Spring morning. I was almost
afraid just to believe the truth of the message for fear it was only a false
report but it was corrobarated last night. My brother and sister have
motored this morning to Sandymount to look after an uncle and aunt who live
there. They were in a very hot spot, I shouldn't be a bit surprised if
word comes that Uncle Richard is dead. Later. (I saw Uncle Richard later
he is looking well, Their one servant had been marooned at Killiney and I
think the extra work helped them. They had had 6 soldiers in to tea one
night 'bayonets and all' as Uncle R. said. I don't think Uncle R will
ever speak of soldiers again as 'Hired assassins'. Their house has been
searched as were all the houses. Their sweep, a Sinn Feiner, was shot close
by.)
He is a serious man with a weak heart. They tell me that the
women were fighting as well as the men. The shop girls were firing
out from the houses at the soldiers; one girl shot a priest who was
supporting a wounded officer. Even after the surrender one could hear
the guns firing and we were told that was in the outlying districts in town,
where the news had not yet reached.
Yesterday a lot of policemen were killed up at Garrystown in County
Meath, the rebels have been seizing the Barracks in country districts
using them as a forte or carrying away ammunition they could find. Many
Sinn Feiners fled to the mountains yesterday and one district there was a
scrimmage with the soldiers among the hills.
I wonder what sort of news you in England are getting about Dublin;
the Government have only themselves to thank for the whole trouble.
Birrell is the man who is chiefly responsible for this terrible
calmination and if Sir- Maxwell with full plenary power had not been sent
across on Thursday there would have been no surrender today.
One cannot help thinking great pity for the country lads belonging
to the Irish Volunteers army who were decoyed up to Dublin by hundreds
on Easter Monday, thinking they were merely coming for the usual parade
and then forced to take part. They were kept in ignorance of the plans for
two good reasons. They would never have come if they had known what was
likely to happen and also assuredly would have let out the secret and
spoilt all. However I suppose they have had some comfort in the thought
that they were laying down their lives for their country, the unfortunate,
misguided lads. "Eoin Mac Neill".
It seems that John Mc Neill, Head of the 'Irish Volunteers' and
Professor of the National University, did not intend this rising to take
place now. He wished to postpone it for 6 months in order to make
further and better preparations; but James Connolly (member of the D
Corporation, head of the Larkinites and Editor of the Workers Republic)
was anxious to carry it off now and Mc Neill was out voted. Monday.
They were unable to reach Sandymount yesterday. They were away
many hours and I was very anxious as two men bicycled out from Foremore
and told me that though the Sinn Feiners under H. Pearse had surrendered
the citizen army (Larkinites) under James Connolly had refused to
surrender and were still at it. Later in the evening from the garden
we could hear the incessant booming of the big guns; G &C.brought back
English papers from town; we could see by now you'll have some idea of
whats going on over here; but the casualties are grossly underestimated.
Yesterday in the R C Chapel here at both masses, Father Harly
offered prayers for the dead and dying Irish Volunteers and never a word
about all the soldiers and policemen who have fallen.
Ellen, our cook said it was most pointed. Its a grave scandal,
several other R C's have made the same complaint, most likely that old
Harly brute is a Pro-German. Monday May 1
We were over at Dunshaughlin today posting letters; we hear that
they go to England via Navan and Belfast. In the post office window
was the full notice in writing probably written out by a policeman——
'The Sinn Fein Leader, James Connolly unconditionally surrendered
to the General Officer, Commanding - in -Chief in Ireland.
Those leaders anxious to avoid further bloodshed have signed a
notice to the other Leaders and their parties both in Dublin and in the
country calling on them to surrender as their cause is hopeless".
The post mistress said this was the latest news and it came this
A M. In spite of the two surrenders, the guns are heard again this
evening. On the way home, we heard with much sorrow that the Co-Inspector
of Meath, Alex Gray, has died today from the wounds he received
in the Garristown affray.
We had heard that his hands were very badly shattered, he must, I
fear, have suffered horribly. He was D I some years ago in Lucan.
Smith, the D I of Navan was killed out right at the same time.
Sir Thos Myles has not been killed after all; but he was captured
by the Sinn Feiners and taken by them to Richmond Hospital to attend to
their wounded.
A very unfortunate thing accurred in Guiness' Brewery last evening
we heard from a friend who is employed there as a clerk; two of his fellow
clerks and two officers who were on the premises doing night duty were
fired at and killed by a sentry because they had not electric torches in
their hands. That (carrying lights) was to be a sign that they were not
marauders. Tuesday
Although the rebels have surrendered unconditionally; at Chapelizod
and in other parts, sniping still continues; several hundred mounted
Infantry are in Dunboyne; presumably to surround the Garristown Camp (400
Sinn Feiners) or to waylay a contigent from the South. Thursday. 4.5.16
We were in town yesterday, G & I. He has a pass through the city
and all women and children are now let in without let or hindrance.
There is not very much sign of the fight until one gets to Sackville
St; there the scene is just appalling; Henry St and Abbey St are pretty
bad too; I need not write about them, you can read all about the
desolation in the papers. We went up and down thro' the city; looking
up various people whose friends were anxious about them.
I ran up against Dr Douglas Hyde (Dr Hyde founded the Gaelic League
he was not a Sinn Feiner but many of his friends were. He never believed
they would actually rise), near Baggott Street Bridge. He told me he was
heartbroken; his friend T McDonagh (a clever literary man, a poet and
a Professor of the National University) had just been tried by Court
Martial and shot that morning and also P H. Pearse, Head of St Enda's
School, Count and Countess Plunkett (their son, Joseph Plunkett, a Sinn
Fein leader, was tried and shot on Friday), and many others have been
arrested.
J. Connolly is in hospital with a gunshot in his leg. I suppose they
will shoot him when he recovers. He is one for whom I feel no pity.
Occasional sniping going on even yesterday. We can now get the
Irish Times and the Evening Mail is also out. In it we read that three
out of the seven signaturessignatories of the notice proclaiming the Irish Republic
have been tried by Court Martial and shot vis; T Mac Donagh, P H Pearse,
and T J Clarke, the last named was a long standing rebel; he was a Feinan
of the old days; he was sentenced to penal servitude and when he had served
his time he came back to Ireland and has kept a little shop in a back street
on the North side of Dublin selling tobacco, and seditious newspapers.
